review_title: Good as first job for fresh graduate
pros:
1. Accepts graduates from a wide range of study disciplines.
2. Offers permanent role, therefore comes with good benefits and prestige.
3. Provides a support system especially as a newcomer in the company.
4. The pay is definitely in a competitive range in the market.
cons:
1. The interview to get in is super tough, therefore, the expectations that come from being an MA is pretty high.
2. Career progression is not as guaranteed (not necessarily going to be promoted on a faster track, this is one possible misconception)
3. The branch acts as a sales and marketing arm of Samsung, therefore do not come in thinking you can do anything tech-related.
4. The work environment is very fast-paced, if you are in a busy department, either you are swamped with work/overworked OR are completely ignored because the seniors are too busy to train/guide you.
Advice to Management
If you are serious, do consult any of the existing MAs there to clear any confusion or concerns!

review_title: Good place to work, at least for a couple years
pros: Similar to a standard strategy consulting firm, Samsung GSG provides a good exposure to different markets/sectors, in terms of geographies (I worked on global and US-focused projects) and sectors (I worked in 4 different sectors, only 1 of which was related to the mobile business). Work environment overall, as a Global Strategist, was pretty healthy, with good work/life balance and a very international working environment.
cons:
Unfortunately, the long-term staying power is low and attrition high in the office. GSGers have standard 2yr contracts when entering, stipulating that you either must be allowed to stay in GSG or must go into the Korean-based organization before transferring out of Korea. Very few people are allowed to stay in GSG beyond the 2yr contract (project leader life is very busy anyway), and opportunities in Korea Samsung are often restricted and not very appealing, meaning that a large percentage of people leave after 2yrs. The transition from the Korea Samsung to other offices around the world is also difficult, with little support to make that jump.
Be the first to find this review helpful

pros:
1. General work life balance - (may be interrupted depending on the team you're in)

2. Good transportation network across NCR.

3. Employees you'd actually have to work with, across teams, are usually nice and helpful.

4. Lots to learn, if you're interested enough to read code properly.
cons:
1. Not much software or tasks to develop.

2. Management lacks spine, to stand up to HQ. Opinion of HQ is to be set in stone. Similarly, opinions of engineers don't matter, until the same is re-iterated by HQ and then management would actually believe. 

3. Disparate salaries for freshers from different colleges, for essentially the same work. Experienced engineers have lesser salaries than new-joiners.

4, Hard-work doesn't pay off for freshers (or anyone), if you're not in a position of importance. (Reasons will always be cited as bell-curve maintenance).
Advice to Management
Try fixing compensation, based upon job profile and not college. 
Upper management (apart from a handful) lacks technical understanding. Not sure how you could fix that.

pros: New 5G technology, employee package.
cons:
Micromanagement
From Senior Management, Management, Team Lead expect this at all level. 
I don't mean to be Race discrimination here. 90% from this Telecom Division (EMS/OSS( are Indian origin hence expect a Indian working culture. 

No Work/Life environment
when working with this division expect to work 12-16 hours/day, haft of the time work on weekend and in my case as T3 support expect to work/attend Maintenance Window (12AM-5AM) during software upgrade. More over. You are expect report upgrade process at 9AM internal meeting. There are only 4 people in the T3 team and each group is 2 people, hence rotation is every other week. I wish I have known this working hours, hence no-transparent is the norm. Shouldn't there be a working hour law, requirement and disclosure?

Growth and Development.
Learn/train on your own from documents and internal Video session
Documents/MOP are un-organize,. Try to find the people who last updated the document and/or latest document on his PC.

pros:
Staff discounts but other benefits are minimum standard
Staff are given the latest phones and laptop
Good pay including generous bonus
Free parking, clean office premises and nice coffee machine
There are still nice people to be found and at a team level, there are some attempts for a good culture.
cons:
The place can bring out the worst in people - being political, cunning, callous and cold-hearted. These are mostly the ones who survive long term and get high performance reviews. Some people are too wrapped up in themselves to care for others or how their actions impact others.
Advice to Management
Employees in Australia need to accept the culture rather than try to change it. Working there does help one grow but only to a certain extent before getting disillusioned or losing their humanity just to survive. 
There are good people who have not been playing the game and are still decent human beings. If you can hold on to them, well done. Note that it's not the usual bunch of people often recognised for their contributions.

review_title: Improving work environment, but still room for growth.
pros: Great pay and benefits. Work life balance is improving. Stepping out of the early 2000's and making efforts to modernize employee perks similar to other large tech player (i.e Peloton reimbursement).
cons:
Oversight from Korea feels like you report into two leadership teams at times. Unstainable appetite for reporting and data that detracts from ability to manage day to day business tasks. No stock options. Career advancements only occur during one period annually.
Advice to Management
Continue to modernize the employee perk and the work life balance to attract and retain top talent.

cons:

Software certification exams happen everywhere but here in Samsung at the height of pandemic people were made to come to office for giving a certification test. They had to give Corona RAT test and hundreds were made to sit in a single hall. All this because someone in Korea had set a demand for employees to clear the certification.
Advice to Management
Please shutdown the HR department of Samsung

cons:

People are scared and trust is low. Be patient in fixing those problems.

pros: Singaporeans here are okay and easy to work with. Mega fast pace environment, good if you like efficiency.
cons:
Alot of cons:
- top down structure
- korean dynasty, only koreans will progress and all top managment are korean
- in out gantry to track all your movement including toilet time
- crazy working hours, expected to work on weekends 
- emails coming in every minute of the day. You can work till 12am and start work the next day at 9am, but having 30 emails to clear in the morning.
- pay doesn't match out with similar external roles 
- staff turnover here is less than 1 year, people come and go very quickly and processes are all new.
Advice to Management
Please value employees more and have more headcount, so work can be distributed.

review_title: Average workplace with Raj mindset, compromised culture and ethics
pros:
Easy worklife, decent pay, infact at senior levels you are overpaid to the value you bring.
Minimum outcome ownership, primarily execution checklist driven, so you can't go really wrong here.
Large scale of ops
cons:
A small scale re-purposing of East India Company culture having Korean C-levels, VPs and next level Indian leadership as Zamindars & Khan Bahadurs.
Leadership is not very industry celebrated and in general lacks spine and vision, with rare exceptions, and indulged into zamindari feuds on work, team and credit grab.
Exceptionally few relate to the place, trust leaders, company or other teams, and vice versa.
Employee audits by multiple teams are a constant and the most indulging part. Actually, this is a reasonable step by Koreans given the compromised work ethics observed over time.
Well HR can be better titled as Harassment Resources than human... Succinctly, to be on blacklists for any decent MNC and big Indian Corporates and can be easily replaced by standard chatbots for efficient ops and lesser demotivation to junta. They have won awards for getting folks to Office during Covid in May and maximizing attendance. In fact sister concern Cheil was bashed up on Social as employees lost life, although it was managed meticulously.
Search on and speak to inside folks.
Advice to Management
Nothing. Everyone and especially the long tenured folks perched atop are very well versed on prevailing things, but.. 'hey I have to save my...job'

review_title: Large company, it will all depend on your team/department.
pros:
Samsung is a large firm. It all depends on your team/department.

In my case pros are:
* competent teams (you work mostly with engineers, often managers have technical knowledge),
* a lot of AWS,
* changes are dynamic and are based on best solution wins approche,
* good bonuses and base salary
cons:
* plenty of projects end up on POC (proof of concept phase),
* before pandemic there was no way to work from home,
* red tape in some departments

pros:
Good benefits, including HMO
Generous starting salary
Samsung product discounts
cons:
Management taking in new projects while not compensating for the amount of new hires. Current employees get stretched too thin to multiple projects.

Employees are also pushed to commit time to more than just one project, these include demands for additional projects, research, workplace participation and monthly exams -

These monthly exams are focused on niche developer topics like software algorithms that not every software engineer is well versed and skilled in for practical application in the industry.

- End of year cash bonuses (based on performance) is great
- Development of skills with free lectures by employees
- Health insurance + life insurance
cons:
- Low annual merit increase, in a time of much inflation of food prices
- No allowances for increase electricity bill / internet bill during wfh
- Depending on your manager, can get stuck on your project / can feel like what you're doing is useless
Advice to Management
- Consider increasing merit increase, and allowances
- Manager should make sure that what their employees are doing are indeed useful

pros:
- Amazing pay and quarterly bonus (managers & above)
- Great health insurance
- Good PTO policy
- Great employee discount on products
cons:
- Can't use your amazing PTO because the company is so short-staffed, there is no one to cover for you
- Work/life balance is non-existent (between the insane amount of work and calls at midnight with HQ, when are you supposed to sleep?)
- Leadership just does whatever HQ (S. Korea) tells them to do, which changes daily
- Impossible to be promoted
Advice to Management
You cannot expect employees to work 60+ hour work weeks every week with little to no burn out. It would be one thing if there was a coherent and consistent strategy, but there is literally no strategy. Everything boils down to "beat Apple" (sorry.. "beat LO"), or... "what is the competition doing? Ok do that but faster and cheaper." 

It's a great company to have on the resume, but get in and get out. Even 10+ year veterans are running for the hills.

pros: They have a lot of resources for you to learn and hone your skills. Colleagues are friendly.
cons:
A lot of overtime, a lot of projects, and a lot of other activities and goals that they want you to accomplish in a year. Salary improvement is slow. Overtime pay is rare now with COVID and mostly everyone working from home. I've seen many of my colleagues stretched thin and many more burnt out, I'm experiencing it myself. This has always been a problem, but it's more obvious with COVID.
Advice to Management
Maybe limit the projects in progress until there are enough people to actually work and focus on it fully.

location: Homebush, New South Wales, New South Wales
pros: Great employee discounts via an online portal, lots of progression and opportunity.
cons:
- Never appreciated. No matter how hard you work, it’s never good enough.
- It’s not the norm to leave at 5:00 or even 5:30pm, people usually work an average of about 10+ hours, then continue at home.
- Even a simple request, goes through layers of approvals, up to the co-presidents of the company. Waste of time & resources.
Advice to Management
Improve culture at the workplace, you need a team dedicated to improving the work practices, company culture & employee incentives.

pros:
Lots of perks and benefits
You'll feel well taken care of
Full of talented people to work with, you'll learn a lot.
cons:
Traditional, as expected from Asian companies
Heavily hierarchical
Has this culture of manager idolatry. They prefer giving more credits to managers instead of the actual programmers when projects are successful.
Advice to Management
Modernize the org structure to be more on a par with western tech companies.
Don't give special thanks to managers over programmers. Either the credits are equal among the team, or the credits be given more to engineers who actually worked "on the ground".

review_title: Join Samsung if you want to taste a colonial era
pros: Good infrastructure, brand. none other than this
cons:
My first day at Samsung- At the lift lobby, There was total chaos. People were pushing each other to reach at Entry door for card punching. I was shocked to learn that timing is 8:30- 5:30 (HR didnt bother to tell me this befoe joining). A minute delay mean one day loss of salary.

My first day on floor- Floor has a look of Korean concentration camp where all Indians were sitting at one side and their Korean boss were sitting another side at big cubicle. Shocked to overheard Young Korean yelling at his old Indian subordinate in his fifties"You are fired". Got to know from one of my colleague that Korean bosses yelling at Indian is not new in Samsung. 
Indian management do not listen to Indians, they wait for their Korean boss to respond. Even HR will disconnect your call abruptly and do not respond to your emails if you try to raise any question. 
Right from the time of onboarding experience till the time of exit, you will have worst experience in Samsung.
Your only Survival in Samsung is when you have nice Korean boss and he is happy with you. They try to vent their frustation by Yelling at Indians.
Advice to Management
Empower Indians by giving them authority for decision making

review_title: Pro's & Con's or working for Samsung Electronics
pros: When working for one of the most valued and followed brands in the world , just the title alone can take you far, and keep you in any other IT job longer than anyone else. The diverse roles and job functions you do there are only going to serve you well when you leave. You can agree a pretty decent compensation package, and they are real generous when it comes to healthcare.
cons:
The cultures are difficult. Everyone says it when you interview, so you have to believe them. Lots of overlap between departments leads to a lot of confusion about the roles and responsibilities and ways of working. And this makes the job much much harder.

You pay people $100+ salaries to do surveys, data entry, and run around like their pants are on fire. There is no consistencies in R&R and too many internal meetings (1 set with USA, 1 set with Korea) and not enough customer meetings.

pros: Facilities, Learning Opportunities, Strong HR, Average to high pay ranges.
cons:
Male dominated environment leads to very aggressive styles bordering on bullying. Sales is the focus and marketing is not supported / seen as order takers.
Any project is slow to get off the ground as between 7-14 approvals are needed for any level of spend. Finance approvals for projects can take anywhere from 1 week to 1 month. 
Over 30% of time is spent chasing approvals and filling in extensive process documentation.
Little to no market research in certain divisions, lots of internal politics with mid senior levels undermining VP direction.
Huge turnover -- most people spend 3-5 years max. in company.
No work/life balance.
A lot of reporting, days and evenings spent writing and updating reports for the sake of showing work is being done. 
Company is driven by finance, then sales. Lots of blindspots and short term focus.

review_title: Its been stressful the whole time
pros: You learn a lot in a short period of time. The bonus are good
cons:
The company thinks and treats their employees as tools, not people. Its a vertical structure so if your boss is aweful you just have to accept it. Ive worked years at the company and never been treated so bad like in the last months. 
Rotation of people are fast. Average of people staying is 1 year. If you dont agree with your director or with your business manager, you have no chance to talk. You will never be heard. The amount of work is always a lot. I used to stay with my team up until 9pm almost everyday.

HR departament doesnt care for the employees. They care for whats best for the company, to dont get sued. And to control employees. So if an employee is not satisfied or motivated, they dont listen to him or her. They just qualificated as bad. 

I literally heard the bosses insulting people in their faces saying strong hurtful words. And nobody could say anything.
Advice to Management
People that always agree with everything are the ones that are afraid of saying whats on their mind. You shouldnt stay with sheeps that always say yes just to dont get in trouble. You should trust in people's talent and improve the way you treat them so they can stay.
Be the first to find this review helpful

pros: Interesting R&D projects, you can learn a lot.
cons:
Very low salaries (if you are not in Korea). You do not get rewarded for inventions. If you make a winning project proposal, it is usually granted to Korean teams, not your team.
Advice to Management
Flatten the structure (7 level hierarchy makes communication slow - it is traditional for Korea, but not for European countries). 
Treat employees from different countires equally - in Poland whole Deep Learning and Computer vision experts team (even group leader, team leader) left to other, less famous companies that easily offer twice bigger salaries in same country. You are loosing talents and it gave Samsung a bad reputation in Poland, as low salary employer - good for a first job to quickly change it.
Employees in Korea with equal degree, skills and accompliishments, have 5 times higher salary than ones in Poland.
Be the first to find this review helpful
Helpful

pros: Nice offices, green spaces and canteen on site
cons:
Miles from anywhere and a nightmare to reach without driving. The company bus sits in traffic for hours, and that’s if you make it out of the office in time for it and aren’t working until late in the night.
You are expected to work all hours of the day and night, especially for monthly deadlines, for no extra compensation and if you don’t it’s frowned upon. Live to work attitude, not work to live. Head office say jump and you must respond with how high.
Most senior staff members placed from Korean HQ, so not a lot of career progression.
Most staff are temporary workers and are treated as secondary to full employees.
No understanding or compassion.
Advice to Management
Learn to live, love and laugh

review_title: Great Pay, Learn a lot, High Stress
pros:
Great base pay 

Big bonuses 

Learn a ton about project management and working for a large company

Great exposure to senior leadership

They send you new devices with every launch
cons:
Very stressful

Work long 20+ hour days, several days a week

The expectation is that you get everything done, it doesn’t matter how it impacts you or how much you’ve already been assigned

No negotiation or give and take, just GET IT DONE

Work-life balance isn’t a thing

Poor people culture
Advice to Management
Hire many many many more people. It is not okay to drive employees into the ground, just because you give them a paycheck. 

Develop a standard for the people culture and actually care about the well being of your employees.

pros: General benefit is good. They try to improve system for employees. There are lots of work to do, therefore you don't need to worry about getting laid off.
cons:
I have Korean background, so I can talk about the actual issues. When I was there, and I am sure it will be the same, Korean employees from HQ are the problem. HQ is sending people to help local branches every 3 or 4 years, depending on their positions, but they won't respect local culture at all. They bring all bad Korean culture to work. Remember that managers in Korea HAVE TO be respected by employees. Managers are god. They can do whatever they want, and even humiliating you in public. This is what those people have. If you have Korean background, then good luck with that. If you don't have it, you will have less opportunities to get promoted. Yes, this is who they are. 

They prefer bi-lingual, because they can control employees badly. These Koreans don't have critical authority for hiring decision but they still do. Those Koreans love to get involved in anything and everything. During any meetings, if you don't get interrupted by them for 5 mins, then you are super lucky. They don't give you opportunities to speak at any meeting at all. I assume that they don't trust you in general. The best part of those Koreans is they are REALLY good at criticizing. They can find what your weakness is and what you did wrong. This is super easy for them. They have Phd for that. 

Korean culture has good and bad, and these people introduce all bad korean culture. Actually, HQ has much better culture based on what friends say. That's why Samsung Electronics reputation is higher on glassdoor than it should be. 

I still recommend it because work is rationally more than okay, and you can learn a lot. If you have ability to ignore their bad etiquettes and nagging, then you can work there. Good brand name on your resume too. Otherwise, you will get stress a lot.
Advice to Management
Please focus on localization.

review_title: Not a place to grow or learn.
pros: You will get a timely salary. They have this competency test to keep checking your programming skills. So most people from Samsung you will find good in data structure. Good to show Samsung name on your resume only. You will have good debugging skills if you are given time to do so.
cons:
Proper training is not there. You need to dig out yourself which is not an issue I believe unless someone starts poking you every now and then, like, "what happened to this issue?" , "Did you complete?" and then after some time "do it fast issues are piling up", "What is taking you so much time to do this simple task?".
I joined and left after 4.5 years (I know it sounds stupid but I was scared of the outside world as if I don't know anything, I can't answer any question(something like imposter syndrome) and I admit it). I changed only after every one of my close friends left finally.
The feeling I mentioned above was all because you don't get time to learn ever. If by chance you happen to open a page from where you can learn something, someone will surely poke you and ask "Oh, so you are preparing for an interview?". Gosh!! Micromanagement everywhere. 
They will overload you with the issues and would want you to fix it on that very day. You get issues at 5PM you should finish it even if it takes you 12AM midnight; you stay; you complete; you go. (In some teams of course and unluckily it was mine). You are nothing but a bug fixer in the eyes of HQ guys. But I think you can learn more and get into any flow deeper if you are in Korea or in the Bangalore team than in the Noida office. You get into it, stay for 1.5 years or so and just leave(as most of the new joiners are doing there). Due to their competency test, you can be in touch with DS and try applying in top companies.
Advice to Management
Nothing, they do what they want to do. They can stop you from going home (and at worst, they will call you back to office when you are midway to your home and will threaten you with severe consequences if not done so).

review_title: Sounds really good, until you work here!
pros: Great Benefits. Not a physically demanding job. Depending on where you work average pay.
cons:
The foreign work culture is a lot of the time very disrespectful to the American citizen. You are treated like you are less than, if you rank under others. Was told in daily basis that work is more important than home/family life. Paid time off /vacation and sick time are the same. Even with doctor statement you are still punished on point system. Have to give 24 hours notice to use PTO or sick time and avoid punishment points. Very little off time work 6 days every week no matter what. They never promote from within. Very disrespectful to employees. Everyone is overworked and exhausted all the time. High turnover rate.
Advice to Management
Just try to care about your employees a little. Give them a reason to want to stay. Start promoting from within and give your people a chance. Try to lead by example and not rule with fear.

pros: I don't have any to share
cons:
HR leadership. The leadership fails in every way possible. Racism exist but even when you go to the top it's still not being recognized that things need to change.
Advice to Management
My advice is take a look at management and inside the heart of your company's Human Resources. It's interesting that even if you call the hotline or bring notice to the racism nothing will be done. Those that are put in place to help employees deal with these things make empty promises. I was told that my incident would be looked into by the Employee Relations leader in Frisco Texas and she never checked into it. It was almost like she was avoiding me because she never followed up. No matter how I tried to bring light to what was going on regarding HR nothing got done. I was not the only victim there where several of us being overlooked and being denied the opportunities that our white peers were given. What's interesting is I was warned by the very person that hired me. She ended up leaving the company for the very reason I'm posting this. She had a master's degree in human resources, SHRM certification, not to mention several years of experience. They hired someone that didn't have her credentials but had the right skin tone "white". This most agregious thing was being a person with several degrees, experiences and being passed up by those that didn't have close to my Background or education. At every turn they came up with excuses as to why they would not hire me nor those that look like me. Samsung has a very high turn around rate in HR because of this reason right here. The most interesting part was I was told that this happens over and over and over again yet nothing has been done. It's very disconcerting to now that in 2020 you're still being discriminated against because of the color of your skin. It's very ugly when you do everything you can to shine a light on it but still it keeps going and being ignored. So the hotline doesn't nor does employee relations doesn't work so what's next? What I experienced was them trying to hurry up and get rid of me. My advice deal with human resources leadership start from the top and work your way down and you will see.

pros: Product discounts, a few nice people
cons:
Where to begin? Zero leadership, strategy, culture and values, extreme micro management and complete disempowerment, complete lack of trust in employees, very hierarchical, systems and processes that are decades old, unusable and work against you, people and teams that actively work against you, only “yes” people remain whilst all the good staff are pushed or leave, not a place for growth, the ONLY thing that matters is short term sales/revenue growth, absolutely no thought for future sustainable growth, more is more, more sales promotions, more discounts, MORE!
Advice to Management
IF there is a desire to be a great workplace (I stress IF, because I don’t believe they actually value employees or the workplace), then I would hire only locals into senior leadership roles (on long term contracts), and remove all expats. This would solve a myriad of problems. Oh, and focus on long term sustainable growth driven by a solid strategy.

review_title: A fantastic company to start your career at
pros:
The size and scale of Samsung might give outsiders the expectation that those in entry-level positions are a very small cog in a far larger machine. In my experience this was anything but the case. 

SEUK gives those who want to take on new opportunities and challenges, every chance to do so. I joined as a graduate, and in that time worked on projects and accounts that I never expected I'd be able to. 

Hard work is very much rewarded, and while the extrinsic, financial rewards and incentives are a big plus, its the intrinsic satisfaction from the role that Samsung provides. However, I have no doubt that this varies from department to department, but based on my time there, I'd recommend Samsung to anyone.
cons:
Top-down leadership is very much a factor, but I'd wager this is the same with most multi-national brands.

Internal processes and systems can be slow and arduous at times, with work sometimes being held up by approvals and software issues.

review_title: Samsung RHQ - Never experienced such a company culture elsewhere
pros: Good salary, Reputable MNC, Staff discount for Samsung products
cons:
While the culture at Samsung is generally toxic, it varies by departments. Not trying to play the race card here but departments with majority Koreans are generally more toxic. If your direct boss is Korean, good luck. Each department is helmed by a Korean BM. The reason why it’s called “Korean BM” is because the position is only reserved for Koreans. It’s no secret that Koreans are favoured in this company and career progression is limited if you’re non-Korean. They’re also exclusive and tend to speak in Korean amongst themselves. Working here is like living in a Korean drama every day. The culture here is extremely hierarchical, bosses love to micromanage and do not give two hoots about their subordinates' opinions. People here tend to groupthink since in Korean culture, having a different opinion is frowned upon. It's no wonder Samsung is falling behind Apple in terms of innovation. Also, senior management tend to throw their weight around and are verbally abusive (seeing the management yell at their subordinates, slamming things, etc is a very common sight). 

Samsung’s management leads by fear and not by example. Machiavelli's "better to be feared than loved" philosophy describes their management style and they’re truly an epitome of Machiavellian style leadership. This can be seen from Samsung's implementation of a clock-in system whereby notifications are sent out to the department heads even if an employee is just a few minutes late. Notifications are also sent out if one under-clocks by a mere few minutes. E.g. if you start work at 9am, something urgent cropped up, and you leave at 5:58 rather than 6pm, the system would send a notification to your boss and you would then have to submit a valid reason in the system on why you under-clocked, for your boss's approval. Employees at Managerial level and above are also not allowed to carry any unused annual leave forward. Work from home is not permitted as well so staying late to OT is a must. In view of COVID-19, the company has allowed quarantined employees to work from home. Even then, activity and hours clocked on their laptops are tracked. Company has plenty of other rigid systems in place, such as mandatory use of their outdated in-house email portals. You also have to submit tedious approval requests for every single thing and the red tape in this company contributes to inefficiency at work.

P.S. It seems like the average ratings here are pulled up by retail staff/promoters. If you look at ratings from corporate staff, they're mostly negative.
Advice to Management
Nil

review_title: You cant spell Nepotism without Samsung
pros:
Some good people to work with

Samsung looks nice on your CV

Cake day
cons:
Contractors and Permanent staff getting treated differently with training, going to summer and Christmas events.

Really bad career progression.

Manager hasnt really bothered taking time hiring quality staff.

Zero experience staff joining the company at higher rank and higher salary
Advice to Management
Its really bad to see staff members been put through there paces to apply for promotion or managerial role only to find someone with no training experience, no relevant background been put forward to a higher management position. Only because they knew someone higher in the company to be put forward for the role. Dont be surprised if you see someones, friend, husband or wife join the company only because they wanted the money and not the job. This hasnt once, its happen multiple times.

Internal recruitment and HR have to put up with it and then having to give some long winded speech on why they are better then you. HR and internal recruitment are just bad people and they will fold down to upper management to decide who enters Samsung. 
Its really embarrassing and I feel bad for some of the more highly talented people I worked with to hear them say that to me. Unfortunately, nine times out of ten, they would just leave and find better jobs who respect there talent rather then who they know in the company.

Samsung can make the company better but because the work culture in some departments is basically: “No one cares what you think”. Theres no point in working in such harsh conditions.
Theres a also a bully culture at Samsung which again, why no one speaks about it? Its simple: HR doesnt care and wont do anything about it. 

Enjoy working with talentless people.
3 people found this review helpful
Helpful
Share

pros: I thoroughly enjoy working at Samsung Research. The people make it for me. As a new employee I have found the leadership team are open, transparent and encouraging . Everyone I've met have been friendly and welcoming. It's a mature culture whereby I've been given the trust and support to suggest new things and shape my own role. There is a great learning culture with constant opportunities to upskill and grow knowledge. It's very much a multi-cultural environment which creates opportunities to collaborate from many different perspectives. The social side is great, in the short time I've been here there have been several team lunches and I hear the Christmas & summer parties are epic! We have a heavily subsidised canteen onsite that offers both western and Korean food. The pay and benefits are also very competitive so all in all it has been a great career move for me.
cons:
None that I can think of!

pros:
Benefits and pay are highly competitive, (but they have to be based on what is in store for you as an employee.)
Well known brand for consumers. (Too bad it doesn't translate to employees or partners)
cons:
The worst company culture I've ever experienced, seen or heard of. You will be worked to the bone. No balance at all. Ever. And forget about any onboarding, development, tools or resources. You will be provided with nothing and expected to navigate the most outrageous hurdles at the same time. 

Additionally be prepared for toxic people in the masses. Not just one or two.... most. Including leaders and HR. Everyone had been conditioned to back stab, manipulate and tear each other down. And you can't trust HR or ER to do anything about it. There has been sexual harrasment, code of conduct violations and serious discrimination especially against women. HR knows about it and brushes it off. And In some cases they even participate in it. No urgency. No concern. No action. 

Micromanagement is constant from all levels. You will be handcuffed and expected to run around like a chicken with your head cut off on the least impactful and most meaningless work. Dont expect to enjoy any PTO either. You are always on. Unless you are a low performing dirt bag. Then you will be protected and allowed to make everyone miserable with your terrible attitude all while everyone that is decent and hardworking is expected to do your work.

Everyone will try to place blame on Korea but the reality is you just have a cesspool of nasty, inept and terrible people at one place with no accountability.
Advice to Management
You need an overhaul of your HR, ER and legal department. They are TERRIBLE. They are inept. Most don't even have real HR/ER backgrounds or experience and legal is too busy covering for the misfits and the "risk" they might present to care about the high performing individuals. 

You can't be employee centric when the only employees you care about are low performers and despicable characters. 

Get it together Samsung.

pros: I rate Samsung very high because I like this company and the effort they do. I had very good relation with the HQ, the VP and the directors.
cons:
I read in previous reviews that the atmosphere at Samsung Staines is very toxic. Some have said that they had bad experience working with people of Indian origins. 

I don't generalize, but my experience working in a team where the majority were of Indian origin was not good. I felt there is a lot favoritism and pressure. Hindi is the main language (we're living in England). They use their mother tongue as a language of exchange, so that you don't understand. You feel you're there, but outside what is happening. A complete dilemma.

The team lead is very rude and offensive. I had to report him to the HR, but I did not do. I don't like to report. I joined the company to work and promote the business.

Finally, a European R&D should receive people with a research background. People who have validated their degree in Europe or got an equivalent of the degree they hold.
Advice to Management
Some people at the HR are also not honest. I advise the HQ or the the higher management in Staines to take a look on what is happening inside the teams. I advise the higher management also to check if the HR are not selective, discriminatory. A person there (I don't mention their name) has made my arrival very hard, leaving me without badge for 4 days. I could not access the business and I had to borrow other people's badge or wave someone to let me in.

Repor

pros: You get a paycheck, 10 days of PTO (for the entire year), No vacation time, health benefits are good
cons:
This is the most unethical, unorganized, and unstable place I have ever worked at. Be prepared to work six days(12 hours)/week. This is great if you are an hourly associate since you will receive overtime pay. However, if you are salary do not expect to receive overtime pay. Supervisors are paid $12.50/hr on Saturdays. That's right $12.50/hr on Saturdays. We make less than hourly associates on Saturdays. Area Leaders make more than supervisors with all the overtime we are working. Some Area Leaders base pay is over $20/hr and $30+ with overtime. Supervisors are well underpaid (salary range $49k-$70k+) when considering the amount of time spent in the plant as well as the workload. There is a major disconnect between HR and supervisors on the production floor. We are treated like incompetent children by HR. They do not take the time to establish a professional relationship with us. The communication between HR and management here is extremely poor. There is no chain of command in the way information is delivered. Quite often the associates will receive pertinent information before the supervisor. This place is also not a safe place to work at. Safety is not a top concern to upper management. The turnover rate is alarming high. We lost at least 20 salary employees within the month of July alone. I have been working at SEHA for less than six months and I am leaving as soon as I find another job.

review_title: If your young with no family and don't mind being micro managed great job.
pros: Good pay and benefits. First hands on of latest devices. Representing one of the top brands available.
cons:
Look at the track record for the last 10 years layoffs, third party, micro managed. Black out from vacation for almost 6 months Thanksgiving - March 22nd and then summer time almost 2 months. Working every Saturday, Sundays mixed in and major holidays. Feeling of results only not there to help field teams succeed but to insure they are doing their jobs.
Advice to Management
Work with field team closer as support not to micro manage. Have a better plan for execution instead of the internalized, third party, layoffs back and on and on.

review_title: Very process driven company in a non-collaborative environment
pros: Brand exposure and fat marketing budgets
cons:
I was hoping to join the world leader in consumer electronics but I quickly realised Samsung is an old family-owned manufacturing company.
The working environment and tools are counter-productive and not collaborative, so you need to work more to achieve less than in a modern company (no wifi, old PCs, proprietary softwares, internet restrictions...)
They don't empower their employees (all benefits, leaves etc. are minimal) and you constantly need to get approvals for anything you do.
Lastly, if you're not Korean the ceiling glass is a reality, you won't grow any further than Manager level.

pros: Excellent benefits (SEA Only) & decent pay
cons:
Horrible work life balance. Never a set schedule and punished for taking PTO by having to make up days missed once you return. Field sales managers feel like retail employees based on leadership directives, which constantly change by the week. None of which helps with our never ending schedule changes mid cadence which ruins our executive presence in-store. no one really gets reimbursed for mileage so in turn, our car's need heavy maintenance for only about $5-$10 back in return a week for gas. I could go on but all in all, I'm still with the company (for now) so until a better opportunity that's financially rewarding with good enough benefits presents itself, I will reluctantly remain an FSM.
Advice to Management
Listen to your field team. In sourcing your employees isn't a "reward" it's a privilege for you and us all. It grants you the peace of mind knowing we will be out there doing SEA proud with integrity, not for you to work us to the bone until we lose pride in what we do. Respect that we have families and want time with our loved ones on major holidays like Thanksgiving. Please stop rubbing that we're all "One Samsung" and in sourced in our face every chance you get. It makes us want to quit and walk away for thinking you did us all a favor. I once loved my job but am now feeling depleted and unappreciated.

Repor

pros:
- Subsidised canteen
- Flexible working hours
cons:
What an awful place to work. There is a serious lack of management - senior management is generally Korean and therefore there is a big language barrier. Majority of these managers have gained their positions due to their nationality and not their skills, qualifications or experience. You find yourself making most (if not all) of the big decisions on behalf of management. It really is the blind leading the blind. 

You will struggle to gain any recognition or growth unless you are Korean. 

It is a company that operates very much like a small business yet it is a multinational company?! There is no structure whatsoever. No building maintenance, guidelines, processes or training. Actually, you do get training, but on how to address Korean people (not how to use Samsung’s systems etc.) - and that’s only if you are permanent! 

No ability to work from home - in fact you can’t even use a USB stick without permission from HQ. It really is an absurd place to work. 

Samsung’s staff turnover is shockingly high - for a reason! 

In my time there I never once had any discussions about future development, progression etc. It’s like you get a position and you’re stuck there for life.
Advice to Management
- Invest in qualified management
- invest in training for your employees
- look at what other multinational companies are doing to retain their staff

pros: Lunch hour is flexible between 12-2 and each staff only allocated one hour but most of the assistant managers and above will leave on the dot by 12 but only return around 1.30 and start work by 2 pm. Seriously.
cons:
My first few months there was just sitting around with no work to do but my boss have the gall to ask what am i doing when he didn't assign me anything.
I was left to wonder why did they hire when it doesn't seem like they needed any help.
No help, no work, no direction.
They want to do everything but halfway through will cancel everything and by the year end review asked you why haven't you achieve anything
Big bosses barely works, they just show face then throw all the work to the low ranking staff to figure out all the hard work.
Most of the them pretending to work hard but most of the time just busied themselves smoking and playing mobile games in the cafe or rooftop.
Lunch hour is flexible between 12-2 and each staff only allocated one hour but most of the assistant managers and above will leave on the dot by 12 but only return around 1.30 and start work by 2 pm. Seriously.
Once they throw you a project, like a rat, you need to sneak you way to find information that other BUs couldn't care less to supply or help. 
Their MIS division is so incompetent and practically expects you to setup your own laptop and only helps young cute employees. 
Corporate marketing is full of corrupt higher ups taking commissions from suppliers
Retail planning and operations - keeps on sending report that nobody read and the market retail mgmt remains big problem. They know the problems but couldn't care less to fix it
Advice to Management
Stop dreaming of taking too much workloads and then cancelling them halfway. Don't be greed. Pick a few and stick your guns.
MIS division is trash and severely unhelpful. Please do something about them
Investigate Corporate marketing - they full of corruption

pros:
Good benefits. 
If you're lucky, you'll have a good supervisor or manager who will protect you from all the negativities in the company.
cons:
No room to move up. All the higher positions are given to Korean expats.
Can't participate in some meetings as they are in Korean.
Long work hours. More than 8 hours of work each day (around 10 to 12 hours of work) and they expect you to finish everything every day but they will question you if you apply for OT too much and then be blamed if you fall behind. So you end up working extra hours for free if you want to catch up with work.
Orientation talks about how Samsung Values its people and its corporate responsibility. But reality is different. There are managers/executives that shout and yell at employees as if we were in the Middle Ages. And even if the employees complain to HR, the company does not do anything about it as they would rather keep the executive than the lowly employee. Thus, good employees just give up and either stay and be miserable, or resign to preserve their health, or find work with another company.
Advice to Management
Start applying the Samsung Values and truly value your people.

review_title: Worst mistake in my professional career : toxic place, very poor work environment, avoid at all cost.
pros: Leading consumer tech company, decent pay and benefits, but no more.
cons:
Top brass Koreans have absolutely no respect for locals, not even for their own people, they do not trust anyone, their disrespectful military style goes against moral and self-esteem, and creating employee fear is management number one job. Even if you are in an urgent need for a job, do not accept any offer, you will regret afterward, or you will get fired. Attrition is very high and not even justifies the need for a learning opportunity. Poor work-life balance, employees can't comment or speak, just obey, no autonomy to take any decision, just follow orders, Koreans just want robots working for them. HH RR department ignores local country labor laws, and they walk a very thin line while trying to comply with minimum standards, they are just an instrument of senior management to blackmail employees, who must get things done or get fired.
You have a long way to learn respect for your employees. I'm not writing this review to attack Samsung, neither expecting any kind of apology. I´m writing this review to advise anyone wishing to work for Samsung, not to make such a huge mistake as I did, my life was miserable there.
Advice to Management
Respect local people, revamp HH RR

review_title: A company with branding but band employer
pros:
Samsung has the brand that many people look up to. 
Many customers wants to associate themselves to the product and brand .
cons:
You couldn't care less if you lose customers. 
Management does not know how to look after staff , very selective and bias. 
No clue setting direction , spend so much time crafting vision but no follow is through on plans . 
The heads are nothing but "yes man" .
Advice to Management
Its the people that makes the company . You are too arrogant with your brand and treat your staff like they were all working in the manufacturing plant . 
You have no vision , you have not many good leaders, and a big gap between the people that strive to maintain your company name and rapport and the top level management . 
You turn a blind eye with people who are loading fake orders and exporting just so that top level management meets nos and satisfy shareholders. Compliance is a fake word in Samsung .

review_title: PLEASE address morale of the field team
pros: Used to be a great job with a lot flexibility. Those days are toast.
cons:
I don't know who is dictating the schedule of the field team, but it's gone from bad to worse. Used to be a Mon-Fri job. It was awesome. Now, who the eff knows. We get sent out a schedule a week before it starts for the month. Working company holidays, 8 DAYS IN A ROW over Thanksgiving...for no other reason than this greedy company trying to push a few more boxes. The team is miserable, doesn't have 2 days off in a row...I could go on. This has gone from a territory management role to a retail micromanaged position. Don't you dare have more than 3 pieces of swag on your table during table days, or try to spend time with your family on weekends. I'm sure after S10 launches, they will see a TON of turnover. All the good ones are leaving and upper management doesn't give a damn. Oh, and you will only be promoted if you came from the best buy side....a failing program.
Advice to Management
Open your eyes & ears, you're destroying what was a great team. Lift the blackouts ( 7 months out of the year) and kill the weekend work... it's NOT working. Have a flex schedule. ASK for REAL feedback from the team. We are NOT retail employees.
5 people found this review helpful

review_title: A bizzare and odd company to work for...
pros: The gym is fantastic and they have great trainers. They also provide free lunch at the cafeteria and the food is not bad!
cons:
All the strategic direction and decisions come from the Korean headquarters; and unless you are Korean, you are treated like a second-class citizen and your ideas and contributions are not be valued. There is very little transparency and sharing of information within the company. They have no idea how to “collaborate” or “innovate”. Majority of senior executives are from Korea and they are quite rude, disrespectful and raise their voices. HR is unable to shift the culture of the company so that a company that has offices and presence in the US adheres to US values and professionalism in the workplace. Women especially are treated badly as Koreans are quite chauvinistic and expect everyone to bow to them - literally. Despite its new building in San Jose, Samsung is a rotten company!
Advice to Management
You can't run the company as though you are still in Korea. Need to learn and understand the US corporate culture and adapt.

pros: Great ideas how to organize work, continuous efforts from management side to speed up internal procedures, make work more transparent and faster for everybody involved. Clear job duties split, advanced technology which ensures work to be done quickly.
cons:
Weak implementation of great ideas for work improvement, too many internal systems in which employees need to work, complicated guidelines which lead to many internal rejections of submitted requests and cause additional work for everyone involved. Often too strict rules which are very hard to follow, also too high sales targets which are impossible to achieve.
Advice to Management
Pay attention to opinions of employees, respect all employees, not only the ones on high positions, give chance to employees to grow professionally, to transfer from one subsidiary to another, be open to different views than your own opinion and perspective. Don't promote only Korean employees, give chance to local employees too, especially the ones who have been working in the company for many years.

review_title: Do not work here unless you want the happiness taken from you
pros: The office looks okay but management have crapped everyone onto 2 floors, leaving the other 2 floors empty. This is painful as the bathroom always smells, fridges always smells with too many lunches cramped in, and there is always a long line at the kitchen, even for bare basics like water as there is only 2 water taps on each floor
cons:
-toxic environment, no one is happy here. Or they start happy and over time they become miserable
-all good talent leave once they realise how process-driven everything is and nothing else matters but following Korean processes 
-bullying
-no career progression
-you spend 90% of your time doing admin instead of your real job, leaving no time for your real job
-bullying management
-top-down HQ control
-approval path (3 managers minimum needing to sign and approve) needed for everything, even for a notepad and envelopes!! 
-systems are horrible
-laptops and computers are so outdated that they do not work. That is because all the desktops and laptops are 9 years old minimum and need to be thrown out. They use old refurbished parts that are falling apart
-approval path is needed for IT Help (that means 3 managers minimum needing to sign and approve before IT can help you with your computer)
-procurement will try and fault you even if you do nothing wrong! 
-management does not care about you, they don't even pretend they do 
-even if this is a means to an end, everyone looks miserable to be here and are always complaining
-high turnover and restructures every 6 months
-do not bother, get out while you can.
Advice to Management
Feedback has been provided, but no action is ever taken! Putting pressure on people but not providing them the tools to do their work will not ensure anything is ever done.

pros:
Health insurance is good and cheap
Product discounts are nice (not great but nice)
cons:
Newberry is like little Korea. Probably 100 Korean team members running around everywhere making important decisions based on each of their own measurements.
Drastic changes to process almost daily. Most with little or no notice.
Work hours are as bad as I have ever seen. Expect at least 6 working days a week if not 7. 14 to 16 hour days on top of that.
American team not allowed to make any important calls. Your role is only to take the blame.
Everyone there is looking to leave. Honestly the worst environment I have ever been a part of.
Advice to Management
The Korean work ethic in Newberry will never work. Let the Koreans run the place or the American team. Its not working with two drivers of one car. Honestly, I am not even sure who runs this place. Even the Koreans seem to have teams work against each other. Crazy...

review_title: Depend on the team and place can be good or not
pros: Depending on the group/division your job can be funny and exciting. In general, the benefits are good but the salary sometimes are not competitive. In research teams, that I worked, you can participate in the most important congresses in the world. So, we have good chance to overseas travels.
cons:
There are some teams that you will have few chances to learn or grow in your career. The evaluation performance process is horrible and forces managers to apply bad scores for good workers. It happens because the company wants only the best employees, but depending on the team size, the evaluation process might be a shot in the foot. Another bad aspect is the HR. In general, they are not transparent and many policies for employees are unclear.
Advice to Management
Pay attention to the HR and the fragility of managers and directors. There are many incompetents managers. It would be interesting to apply the 360º evaluation process. There are many smart people that are put to be routine and demotivating tasks. Improve the evaluation performance to avoid stack ranking.

pros: For a job in Korea, the company takes good care in terms of foreigners in terms of salary, providing accommodation, three meals a day and additional perks. You are somewhat treated as special in a Korean team, like a guess. The problems are interesting and you will have opportunity to learn new things.
cons:
You will experience severe isolation, you will likely be treated as a contractor and provided with absolute minimal context or background information. Koreans often don't seem to want to hand you significant responsibility. Due to hierarchy and fierce internal politics, managers often don't listen to feedback. Opportunity for promotion into higher management is rare. If you are employed as a senior, principal or master engineer, don't expect them to give you people to manage. Unless for example you are an Indian and they are looking for someone to manage people in India. The problems often have unrealistic goals and fairly few works make their way into products.
Advice to Management
Deal with the hierarchical issues and learn how to utilize the capability of your foreign employees better.

review_title: Managers could learn a thing or two
pros: The benefits are alright, good health insurance and access to Bookster. Salaries are on the market, too, though they could be better (and I am talking here about the Shared Services Center)
cons:
Outdated technology - got a used laptop that was pretty slow and ran on Win 7 (yes, in 2018). Got a used phone and was told that if I wanted headphones, they could disinfect a pair for me. 
The attitude of the managers was really bad - even with little experience, they were not open to make things (or themselves) better, even if the people they had on their teams had a lot more work experience. 
Micromanaging was the law and it cost a lot of people their efficiency and productiveness. 
Was promised a ‘flexible’ work schedule, but was actually forced to work 9 to 5 in the end.
Not doing overtime was frowned upon, even if you’d finished your duties for the day. 
Hiring overqualified people for the wrong jobs - or promising things in the interviews that are not happening.
Not allowing workers to move between teams if that is what they want.
Advice to Management
I could recommend some people management training. Or even the basic - just listen to what people have to say and how they see things.

Cultural and practical gaps with leadership in Korea that is never, ever going to be resolved.
No culture of teamwork or mentorship. You're on your own, all the time. Good luck.
No clear vision or communication of expectations.
High turnover of good people due to all of the above.
Advice to Management
Communicate vision, expectations, goals. Communicate anything, really.
Support your employees. It matters. We feel it when you don't.
Without some clarity and sense of purpose people are going to continue to leave.

review_title: Exciting workplace bogged down by bureaucracy
pros: Great coworkers, fantastic benefits (excellent insurance, with most of the premiums covered by the company, 401K match, excellent employee purchase program). You work with some of the coolest products on the market, and work with some of the biggest technology partners and resellers in the US.
cons:
Too many proprietary systems and processes, I do not feel like my experience here helped contribute to my career prospects in more modern companies. You are constantly working within a Korean mindset, with ridiculous goals often established without any regard to actual market conditions, and can change at the drop of a hat when a new executive decides he wants to try something different.
Advice to Management
Establish more clear and well-defined company/group/team goals, and stick to them. Stick up for your employees when global HQ starts dragging people through the mud. Adopt industry best practices for marketing, and provide access and training to employees on modern marketing platforms and processes.

employee_title: Head of Marketing Consumer Electronics, Retail Marketing Head
review_title: Head of Marketing - consumer electronics, Head of Retail Management - Mobile, CE
cons:
mer Electronics, Retail Marketing Head in Prague
Recommend
CEO Approval
Business Outlook
Pros
- We are able to implement "local ideas" into actual marketing & sales strategies and action plans, time to time we can even influence Global strategies.
- No fear for "changes" culture
- Well structured SCM, Marketing assets
Cons
- less "Brand" focused operation
- Not clear "Pricing Strategy" creates unnecessary price erosion.
Advice to Management
- Samsung have grown up with advanced leadership on technology and super effective hardware manufacturaing ability until now, however when Chinese Brands are copying Samsung's fast follower strategy and it's threathening Samsung's current crown, we must take a step to make Samsung Brand into True Premium.

We must stop doing the "wrong pricing strategy", "burning money into non-brand building activities".
We should value the Brand, and set "sell out action policies", "right pricing strategy", "consumer need oriented product development"

Samsung still have good Brand and great technology leadership, if samsung is able to implement "Brand" and "Right Pricing Strategy", samsung can be unbeatable champ in the market.

pros: Mobile devices is a very exciting category in terms of innovation, and competitive activity.
cons:
mers are extremely engaged with their brands.

They pay extremely well and have two rounds of performance bonus in a year. Overall more cash oriented versus total benefits.
Cons
Culture needs a LOT of work. It's not behaving like a Global/multinational company. It's essentially a Korean company with a global footprint. That says a lot. Korean leaders are considered gods -- and behave as such. Cross them once and you will be marked forever - i.e. subjective performance reviews, delays in promotion, limited exposure.

Furthermore, it's a very sales-oriented organisation at the core -- in contrast to being marketing-oriented as for other global consumer brand companies. That being said, classically-trained brand marketing professionals will not find fulfilment or recognition here as they are seen only as campaign execution drivers rather than drivers of overall brand and business strategy.

There's also no real Global Mobility program. You may get assigned to a 6month stint at HQ -- but it's very poorly planned, as you will practically do nothing, and understand nothing coz they all speak only Korean in meetings. Go figure.
Advice to Management
None.

pros: You will have an opportunity to work with some really great people who are committed to supporting you to make things work (despite the cons, below). You will also be able to work with some great tech.
cons:
Terrible systems and processes - For some reason Samsung has decided to make the operational work environment as inefficient as possible. So many approvals, rudimentary reporting capability and unwieldy systems to navigate (as dictated by HQ).

Senior management is fairly toxic in many teams (especially those coming from Korea). The strict hierarchical nature of the org structure makes two way communication (up and down) very difficult which affects the corporate agility
Advice to Management
Fix up the systems/processes to improve responsiveness to the market demands and reduce stupid overhead on employees.

Create a better method for defining the corporate strategy (in subsidiaries) and executing to plan over the long term

pros: * Work stability, no layoffs
cons:
* They count your working hours. ROFL.
* Huge-size company with every possible Internet restrictions, interferring with your job (slow proxies, broken SSLs, inhibition of entire protocols like tcp/22, forbidden access to socials where software engineers debate techies, etc.)
* Non-trust culture: Everyone suspects everyone else
* No space for technical grow: if you want to take a training, that is NOT included in your worktime. That's ridiculous in a fast-pace muting world.
* If you work as a Software Engineer, you have to take some incredibly messed internal algorithm proficiency certifications in C or Java, not recognised anywhere else of course
* Internal portals are like labirints, impossible to understand. Some work only on Windows. Some may prompt js popups in Korean and kill your browser entirely.
* Bureaucracy for anything that's easy, i.e. if you need a headphone see you must ask 10 approvals, with a chain of command going upto almost the company CEO.
* You can take your first PTO day after at least 6 months, which I think is even illegal
Advice to Management
Update the corporate culture to 2018.

pros:
Some of the best guys to work with and a lot of cool stuff happening. Work is technically challenging. Have learnt a lot here. 

Cabs and Bus Facilities are available. Breakfast, lunch and dinner are available at subsidised rates. Gym facility is available. 

Good Compensation. There is a variable part but it is paid out in full usually.

Patents are encouraged. Open Culture. 

Team members are sent to South Korea on project assignments for short and long term both. Majorly short term.
cons:
Many of the design decisions are driven by South Korean Team. We do have a say but it gets overridden .

Samsung pricing model needs to change. Companies like Redmi, Moto, Lenovo have completely taken monopoly of the Indian Mobile Phone market because of their aggressive pricing strategies and the ability to provide quality handsets at a very cheap price.

Policy of Hiring only from IIT's / Premier Institutes. In my opinion, this is actually a discrimination. A lot of talented people are from non premier institutes. Samsung had a period where they took candidates from non premier institutes as well but it was very brief and then it stopped. I do not know if they have started hiring candidates from non premier institutes again.

They do not provide laptops because of security concerns so the option of WFH is ruled out. 

They have their own internal mailbox for sending emails. It is not good and is a pain to use. They should probably use Outlook or something similar. Not sure of the reasoning behind this.
Advice to Management
Please change your pricing model. Unless this is done, you will not be able to regain your spot in the Indian Mobile Segment. 

WFH option should be provided. Samsung should do something about this.

Keep hiring people from non premier institues. IMHO, when a person is talented enough, it should not matter where he has studied.

pros: The innovative products are appealing.
cons:
Korean HQ sees everyone as a number. This creates distance and creates an environment where everyone is disposable. It is an constant struggle for relevance, with optics constantly outweighing substance. Not a productive or healthy working environment.
Advice to Management
Create longer term placements for senior management (Management try and maximise short term gains, instead of seeing the bigger picture). Create more cohesion between departments, allowing for goals which are company focused, instead of product/division focused. Lastly human capital is your most valuable asset, both Korean and European talent, reflect this in how you treat people.

review_title: biz built on blood n sweat of personal life
pros:
- high salary, if you get the higher s-band (higher eduction, like phd will help you, as well experience working in competitor company)
the salary is really competitive versus other global companies i worked
- it will be very easy to get a job after you get few year experience in Samsung
- if you are not married and don't have children, money and career matters to you more than human values and people around you, this is THE place
cons:
- people imitate there is a lot of work as they want to show how important they are, in reality i could make all the job quickly and had to imitate i work the rest of the time - it is devastating. they really pay attention to your computer screen and you're afraid your facebook even that it can be related to work.
- check in and check out system - 5min late to work and you have to explain why to vice president or HR
- you can't go home earlier, people sit until 18.00 or 17.00 even that they are done
- because of high salaries your colleagues will be ready for everything in order to keep the job - they will tell things behind your back to top management, even though these things have nothing to do with reality, they will not help you with some very specific things in your 3 month period and become more friendly after they understand that you stay, they will be very inhuman, untrue, career oriented robots
-and, yes, non asians will be treated like monkeys. there are rules for koreans and rules for ordinary people
- your korean boss will be betraying you on the meeting to make his career, he will be very unhuman and make you feel under psychological pressure
- be ready that they will test you and come at your table by asking market share of certain product on certain market or something like that - employees really learn KPIs, it doesn't help them making the right decisions, but just answer the korean tests

i will never buy Samsung products, as they are built on the bones of people, from who this corporation sucks out blood with this awful robot-like corporate culture
- they will ask you to work on weekends and spends evenings on business lunches, it's really too much there - they absolutely ignore your private life schedule

review_title: Discriminatory Performance Evaluation Practice to Foreign Employees
pros: Tons of company resources, great benefits, amazing infrastructure
cons:
This company lures foreign recruits to come work at their Korea HQ with competitive salaries. Unfortunately, they do not tell you that there is a double standard for performance evaluations. They never communicated this ahead of time. There was no transparency at all. Foreigners are evaluated at a higher standard because of their higher incomes. You want to hold foreigners at higher standard because of their higher pay? then give them a higher position that would be aligned with their salary so that they can deliver on higher expectations. This is discriminatory. Their bait and switch practice is very questionable and incredibly unfair
Advice to Management
Stop discriminatory practices against foreing hires. You should get rid of the bell curve that you promised to get rid of two years ago. Promote a meritocracy based promotion system rather than the seniority based legacy system that still exists today. You should conduct full 360 evaluations with more than 4 stakeholders evaluating people rather that the current 2 evaluator system which really is a one evaluator system (everybody knows this)
4 people found this review helpful
Helpful

review_title: Improvements needed within culture and professionalism
pros: Great Pay, Great Benefits and Products
cons:
Hierarchical, which would be fine if leadership were stronger. Nepotism is rampant with a healthy dose of extremely, unethical and unprofessional behavior from Sr. Leadership on down. There is a sickness within Samsung, that has been compounded, from previous Sr. Directors to the newest leadership and offices.
Advice to Management
Do your due diligence, audit the last few years of new offices, teams and divisions. Work on collaboration, transparency and hire qualified people. Respect all of your employees and clean up the corruption. Hopefully then you can keep talent as opposed to losing it. Samsung has so much potential, but there needs to be some major cultural and professional changes to right the ship.

pros: Working at Samsung Electronics HQ provided great stretch opportunities rarely available at other organizations. Responsibilities were vast; sometimes discordant which could be an issue for someone looking for structure.
cons:
The top-down ultra-Korean approach to everything can be stifling and suffocating without a strategy. Being pro-active and finding allies is an absolute must. Unfortunately many non-Korean workers never really figured this out.
Advice to Management
To attract global talent, develop global teams that are outside of the strict Korean hierarchical corporate structure and use them as a best practice for traditional teams.

pros: Relatively big budget; HR and internal employee engagement does a great job; team building event every quarter
cons:
Toxic environment; most people spend time on arguing and politics instead of actually doing the work; borderline racist - if you're not Korean you WILL be treated as a second-class citizen; most execs are expats from Korea and are condescending towards non-Koreans, reeks of corporate greed and corruption

Hire local leadership to head up regional offices, stop sending expats as leadership that does absolutely nothing and negatively impacts the business. Samsung has by-far the worst corporate culture I've ever witnessed.

review_title: Good programming experience and well known company
pros:
- Fast paced environment. If you want to grow as a programmer, this company is one of the best starting ground for you!
- Algorithm and certifications exam. Opportunity to learn here is one of the best since they provide good Continuous Learning Programs (CLP) and trainings internally. 
- Easy opportunity for business trip in Korea or in the US
- Excellent minded people. People are well versed in their own jobs as well as their algorithmic capabilities.
- Good management. Managers at the moment are considerate and will make you feel comfortable.
- Discount!
cons:
- High company politics. Don't expect to elevate into the higher ups that easily.
- low increase in salary per annum
- Micromanaging. At the end of the day, work above all else.
Advice to Management
This is a critical issue to the management: take care of your people! You need to identify who are the assets in the company and give importance to them. Wasted talents leave/will leave unnoticed because they want something that you give in another form. (you should get what I mean here)

pros:
Since I came from abroad to work for a branch in Africa, they paid for my apartment (considering the local rental price, $2,000/month), transportation (had a driver who helped me commute) and free quality lunch. Depending on the sales, good compensation.
Looks good on the resume. And after working in such a high pressure workplace, nothing else seem terribly difficult.
cons:
No work-life balance. Koreans are expected to sit around in their desk until their seniors leave work. And they usually work until 8-10pm. When busy, easily passed midnight. High work ethics but no efficiency at work. Expected to be ready to come to work, get on the messenger or answer your phone even in the week-end. Everything's 'emergency'.
Always worked in fear. Higher managers are always extremely stressed under lots of pressure. Managers don't know how to manage people. The whole company needs a serious change in work culture.
Advice to Management
Management must learn to repect and appreciate their employees. Hire more people so employees don't have to overwork for 2-3 people's work load.

pros:
- Innovative products and strong R&D team.
- Big brand name.
cons:
- Political.
- Korean-centric.
- Dictatorial management style.
- Underqualified Korean expariates stationed at overseas offices to take on mid-level leadership roles. 
- These business managers has strong power in decision making but bears little responsibility if outcome is poor. Those under them become scapegoats unfortunately. 
- Appraisal system is flawed, and can be easily influenced by the likings of these business managers. 
- Incompetent HR that only act according to these Koreans' and head office's instructions, and has little mindshare on the welfare of local employees.
- No career development.
- High staff turnover.
Advice to Management
- It was once such a great company, but not anymore. 
- You need to empower local management. Why hire if you don't trust? 
- Too many (underqualified) Korean expariates messing with the overseas business. It is a waste of the company's resources. 
- The culture is so toxic you not only lose an employee, you lose a customer as well.

review_title: All animals are created equal. Some are more Korean than others
pros: The people you sit with make or break your time there. I had GREAT companions in my corner of the building. Sharp, intelligent, warm, and everything a good office should have.
cons:
Contemplating a career here, or know someone who is? 
Point them to these reviews. Save yourself or that person, unless you dislike them!

Turnover is very high because training is non-existent.

Pay is low and likely to remain that way.

Samsung uses legacy technology to solve tomorrow's problems... except the deadline passed yesterday.

The WEBSITE CMS is a botched AEM implementation. HQ is stonewalling to 'save face'.

Bullying and harassment is rife in SERVICE division. 

Attempts to bring in Fair Work Australia have been foiled, most notably in 2014.
I can confidently say Pauline Hanson will devour a "halal snack pack" before that happens. 
 
Some companies dream of heading into space by 2020, like Virgin Galactic. And P0rnhub.
Samsung dreams of "Work Smart 2020 - Building a Creative Culture: Work Smart. Think Hard. Build Trust."
A closer description is: Hard Culture. Build Work. Group Think.
 
All this leads to an inevitable truth. We haemorrhage talent.

If you are starting your career, don't do it here if you have options.
Advice to Management
Bring Fair Work Australia in to investigate Service division under the incumbent Director.
