pros:
Decent Compensation
Lot of Technologies to work on if given a chance
Free and decent food (have to pay for snacks)
If one performs well in their competency test, he/she is very valued and given a choice to choose any team
Some teams are really good with very competent people who really care about career growth of a fresher(I was fortunate to get into one such team)
cons:
Extremely poor HR policies. One example is that when college freshers join, their teams are decided by HR as compared to the people working in the teams themselves

There is a retention bonus policy, wherein one has to work for atleast 3 years to get the assured package, otherwise have to return the retention bonus part of the salary, which is almost 30% of the total annual compensation .

Extremely tight security. Cant take laptops out of office. Cant bring anything like usb, ipod, etc inside. Hence, can't work from home.

No wifi in office. Even the ethernet speed is very poor(~10 Mbps)

Lot of disparity in compensation and general behavior between IITians and non-ITians.

Work life balance in most of the teams is poor. 

HQ in Korea makes all the decisions. No ownership of any project, except some really bad projects who don't have any commercial value.

Some teams are called to work in weekends, while other teams hardly work half the time they are in office.

No recreation in office, other than a Foosball table and two tt tables for ~5k employees .
Advice to Management
Please listen to feedback from employees and fix the HR policies. If some things are changed, the company has the potential to rival likes of Google and Microsoft.

pros: Great benefits package and cheap on site meals.
cons:
- Salary is much lower than what the industry offers
- Poor management, they simply do not care for giving objectives or explaining the impact of work being done. Things are simply threw at you from Korea and deadlines are usually rushed
- A lot of language barrier, most managers are Koreans and the important documents are all in Korean. If you don't speak Korean, you don't get included in important meetings, or you simply receive important documents that you cannot understand
- Some of the staff are unprofessional, rude and have poor attitude towards new colleagues, making newcomers feeling unwelcome
- Management simply does not step in when issues arise or problems are reported, but micro-manage unimportant tasks
- Extreme amounts of red tape, things will take a long time to get done
Advice to Management
- Make sure you give your employees time and the tools they need to get their job done
- Get rid of bad people in the company

pros:
Decent salary
Generous perquisite for expat (working abroad)
Training/education program is really top-notch
cons:
All pros I mentioned above is the 'PAST'. Company rapidly chopped down cost from them.
Long working hours - if working abroad, 12 hours a day/ 6 days a week is -as a minimum- required - only for Koreans. 
Current CEO is hopeless - No business insight in construction/ No plan
Greatly affected and influenced by Samsung Group - You cannot do what you want.
Admin staffs always reign over engineers (You must feel disrespected)
Advice to Management
Samsung construction used to be a very good company. They build top 3 world skyscrapers, incheon and yeongjong bridge. No such projects since then - for 10 years. Now we cannot say we're good and experienced. Please change CEO (Chi Choi) who knows business and who is willing to do business. If you don't want construction business, just sell it, not making people withered.

review_title: What we get to learn on the job here at Korea HQ.
pros:
- Unmatched silicon tape-out schedules due to fast tape-outs owing to tight product schedules
- We get to learn a lot about silicon behaviour of the circuit we design
- If the tape-out cycle is every 3-months, we can get silicon-wafer level feedback 4 times a year 
- This gives us an almost 2~3 times steeper learning curve as compared to most other companies in this industry. 
- Good salary packages
cons:
Very tight product schedules
Not much time to innovate, plan, think, and brain-storm with colleagues
Colleagues are almost non-conversant in English - slows down the learning curve
Advice to Management
Give more flexibility to your employees in terms of work hours, work-from-home, overhaul the performance evaluation system.

Koreans are not good towards the indian employees and impose weird and strict rules.
If you are a talented person, try to get out as soon as you can. If you are average/below average programmer, work hard and survive here.

review_title: Frustrating if you like anything you work on to actually launch
pros: Good salary and benefits, plus you will get to work with some very smart colleagues.
cons:
Culture is absolutely hierarchical throughout all levels of the business. 

Korean management hire very senior Western leaders and then do not give any subsequent degree of autonomy or leverage to them, leading to very obvious frustration and demotivation which filters down to staff at lower levels of the organisation. This breeds an extremely negative working environment where individuals will quite openly criticise the company.
Advice to Management
Respect the experience of staff that you hire into individual functions - and consider whether the culture you have will suit certain people you interview before bringing them into the business. Realise that by increasing motivation you will also increase productivity.

review_title: Stay away from this place. Stay healthy.
pros: I don't want to consider punctual salaries as a pro. To work is your duty, to be paid is your right.
cons:
If it really does exist the concept of circus in a company, you can find it at Cheil Industries. No job descriptions, no roles, only lies. Today you can be a manager and tomorrow you will be used as a warehouseman, independently from your background and expertise. Don't hope to make a career there inside, unless you are Korean. The biggest risk is to forget how to work, as there inside you just play something unintellegible. There is a huge difference of salary treatment among Korean people and other ethnicities' ones. They will try with all their efforts to keep some money from your settlement, when you leave, as they consider a shame the fact that you're leaving this company and they will get offended like children. It is strong their attempt to make you think as a Korean, as they don't want to accept that they're working in a foreign country. The management is composed by people that don't even know their name, nor why they've been put there.
Advice to Management
Change everything or everyone will leave this zoo.

Report
Samsung Electronics Response
Employee Relations
Thank you for your feedback, we have initiated Samsung New Culture last year 2016 July to encourage work life balance

pros: Global reach. Mega brand which can get you a meeting with almost anyone. Chance to see/develop some cutting-edge new technologies if you are so lucky. As a foreigner at Korea HQ, you may be thrust into a role which gives you a chance to see the world through business trips. 3 free meals a day at the cafeteria and free shuttle bus transportation to/from work.
cons:
Initiatives and executives come and go at the blink of an eye. Poorly-defined roles & responsibilities for most employees -- this ambiguity causes a lot of project overlap among groups and you often find 2 groups working on the same project simultaneously, unbeknownst to each other. Excessive politicking. Little collaboration between groups. Still a very strong Korean hierarchy and junior level employees don't take personal initiative or accept accountability. Important meetings are held in Korean language and as a foreigner you get left out -- unless you have somehow mastered the language on your own time as Samsung does not provide Korean classes for its foreign employees (you do receive a budget for education but no clear way to use this effectively while working a full-time job). No flexibility at all to work outside the office, and your hours are tracked; i.e. you must sit at your desk for 9 hours/day even if you have nothing to do!
Advice to Management
Where to start??? Two tips for managing foreign employees at Korea HQ... (1) Clearly define roles for foreign employees before they start work, and clearly define objectives which they will be measured against. (2) Either establish a policy to communicate in English when foreign employees are present, or provide intensive Korean-language education on campus during work hours so foreign employees can contribute productively and not be left out of important discussions.

review_title: Working as a Engineer at Samsung
pros: The work is easy. The people are laid back. Managers don't get on your case about much. Anyone can adapt to this place.
cons:
Management will never give you a clear cut answer. They beat around the bush. It's very segregated here. It's either your one of us or you're not. Many people quit because they are operating this like how they would work in Korea. They want you to get everything done, but don't want you to work over time.
Advice to Management
Be more direct like the old Korea. Don't be afraid. Be firm but affirmative. Be strict but fair. Reward the people who work hard, not reward the people who do no good for the company.

review_title: IF YOU ARE AN EXPAT EXPERIENCED HIRE RUN AWAY
pros:
-Salary only if you can negotiate the moon and stand firm on your numbers
-The gym in Suwon R5 is amazing
-Cafeteria food (while it can get sorta boring) is actually quite good. well for free food.
cons:
Possibly the worst decision ever in my professional career. I was an experienced expat hire having previously worked for other top companies (APPLE, MSFT, GOOGLE...take your pick). Worked for Samsung Mobile marketing...you know the group that puts those dog and pony shows with Korean executives speaking with their poorly spoken English. This place will absolutely rot your soul. You will wonder every day of your stringent 1.5 or 2 year contract, what you are doing there; why you are there; and how to kill time. Every minute of your mandatory 10 hour days (yes, they track your hours and you will get an incomplete if you do not put in your full 10 hours). Yes, you have to go through an airport security system and put your bags through an X-ray machine. i could go on and on. But the most important point is that as a professional hire, you will regress. While you are rotting away in Suwon with absolutely nothing to do, your colleagues back home will be moving up progressively or have worked on something amazing. For more details please check out a book called Noonchi: The Appearance of Working in a South Korean Chaebol for the painful details. Yes, a former employee wrote a tell-all expose because it was the only way to keep sane.
Advice to Management
learn english

pros: Decent, modern office spaces. Reasonable perks and a great name to have on the CV. Some brilliant and very driven people can be found in spots.
cons:
The Korean business culture dominates all.

Decisions making happens at a high level by senior leaders without them consulting or asking for the opinions of their colleagues who are below them in the pyramid but understand challenges in far more detail.

As all the senior leaders are Korean, local teams at each subsidiary have minimal control over anything. Working here makes you feel like a small cog in a large wheel to drive someone's promotion and pay rise in Seoul.

This must also be one of the worst places to work as a woman. No female role models in senior grades at all and I heard outright sexist remarks by colleagues on several occassions.
Advice to Management
Work to overhaul the business culture completely. You have a great opportunity to combine the strengths of both east asian and western working culture. This would make Samsung a much better place to work and no doubt improve performance.
